newsitem.title: FINLAND: Rautaruukki to cut Raahe and Fundia staff.
newsitem.headline: Rautaruukki to cut Raahe and Fundia staff.

text.p: Finnish steel group Rautaruukki Oy said on Monday its investment programme would enable the group to cut staff at its main works in Raahe and at the Fundia unit, despite increased capacity.
Rautaruukki CEO Mikko Kivimaki gave no details on the planned staff cuts. Rautaruukki has earlier announced plans to cut the number of employees at Fundia to 3,000 in 1997 from the current 3,500.
The Raahe steel works had 3,688 employees at the end of 1995.

"There will be a lot of new capacity, and the cost of (running) this new capacity is low since for example the wage impact of this new capacity is positive," Rautaruukki CEO Mikko Kivimaki told a news conference.

The acquisitions of the remaining 50 percent stake in Fundia and of steel wholesaler Keskometalli lifted Rautaruukki's payroll to 12,768 in January-August on average from 9,488 in the first eight months of 1995.
Capital expenditure was also boosted by the acquisitions and Rautaruukki's eight-month gross investment rose to 1.6 billion markka from 550 million in January-August 1995.
Rautaruukki expected the investments to start gradually paying off from 1997.
"The capital expenditures will begin to yield a return step-by-step beginning in 1997," it said in its January-August interim report.
Rautaruukki said its steel output in Raahe would increase 25 percent per person-year through the investments, but the company did not give absolute output figures.
The output of cold rolled production at its Hameenlinna works would increase to 1,250,000 tonnes from 930,000 tonnes and productivity would rise by over 30 percent, it said.
